title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
ExxonMobil's shareholders on Wednesday delivered a stunning rebuke to the oil major's management on a historic day in the fight by climate campaigners against fossil fuel producers.

A majority of Exxon shareholders selected at least two of the four directors nominated by Engine No 1, a tiny hedge fund that has waged a proxy campaign against the company's management led by Darren Woods since December.

Meanwhile, a court in the Netherlands ordered Anglo-Dutch energy company Royal Dutch Shell to aggressively increase its emissions cuts in a ruling that could set a global precedent for corporate polluters.

In addition, a big majority of Chevron shareholders voted for a resolution calling for the US supermajor to “substantially reduce” its scope 3 emissions, or those from the products it produces. The company said it would “carefully consider” the result.

Campaigners hailed the day as a breakthrough moment as the urgency of the climate crisis arrived at the door of some of the world's biggest fossil fuel producers.

Sign-up to Energy Source for regular updates on the energy industry.

Coronavirus digest

  • Joe Biden has asked US intelligence agencies to “redouble” their efforts to investigate the origins of Covid-19, amid renewed questions over the role a laboratory in China might have played.

  • The World Health Organization has called on members to engage with vaccine manufacturers to encourage IP sharing and tech transfers.

  • Scientists in Germany claim to have cracked the cause of the rare blood clots linked to the Oxford/AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.

  • The EU is set to demand billions of euros from AstraZeneca if the company fails to increase deliveries of its Covid-19 vaccine by next month.

  • Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnson's former chief adviser, launched a stinging attack on the UK prime minister over his handling of the Covid crisis. Here are his five most explosive claims.

Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

Tesla set to pay for chips in advance Tesla is set to take the unusual step of paying in advance for chips to secure its supply of the crucial materials, and is also exploring buying a plant as part of efforts to overcome the global shortage, according to people familiar with the matter.

American bank chiefs face questions Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts, and Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase chief executive, clashed over overdraft charges as members of the Senate banking committee questioned the leaders of the US's banking industry about their response to the pandemic.

  • Apple is recruiting a business development manager for “alternative payments”, including cryptocurrencies, to sit in the same team as Apple Pay and the iPhone's Wallet app at its Cupertino headquarters.

Senior Fed official says it may be time to begin tapering debate Randal Quarles, a Fed vice-chair, has called for a debate about tapering the central bank's asset purchases if the US recovery keeps gathering steam. He said that even after “discounting temporary factors”, the increase in US inflation since December would “prove sufficient” to merit a drawdown in asset purchases later in 2021.

Biden under pressure from Democrats over infrastructure package The US president is under pressure from both sides of the Democratic party over his $2.3tn infrastructure package. Moderates want him to strike a deal with Republicans while progressives are urging him to walk away from the negotiating table. Republican lawmakers are today expected to put a new offer on the table worth about $1tn.

Beijing faces scrutiny over Latin American development bank Mauricio Claver-Carone, the recently-installed head of the Inter-American Development Bank, said Washington had allowed China to gain an economic foothold in Latin America by underfunding the lender for years, in an interview with the Financial Times. “For decades, the US, across the political spectrum, has undervalued the IDB,” he said.

The day ahead

G7 trade ministers' meeting Liz Truss, UK international trade secretary, called on G7 trade ministers to back an overhaul of the World Trade Organization ahead of the group's meeting today. The leaders of the EU and Japan hold a summit via video conference to discuss global issues and bilateral relations as well as foreign and security policy. (Telegraph)

Earnings round-up Retailers Dollar General, Dollar Tree and Best Buy all report before trading begins on Wall Street. Dell and Salesforce.com report after the market closes.

Economic data US jobless claims are set to decline for the week ended May 22; orders for durable goods are expected to increase again in April. (WSJ)

UNHRC special session on Palestinian Authority The UN Human Rights Council is expected to approve a fact-finding mission to investigate Israeli actions against Palestinians in the lead-up to and including this month's 11-day conflict that ended on May 21. (Jerusalem Post)

UN civil aviation meeting The UN body that agrees standards for civil aviation is due to hold a meeting after EU leaders urged their countries' airlines to stop flying over Belarus.

What else we're reading

Will MGM be Amazon's ticket to Hollywood's big leagues? Jeff Bezos has for years been desperately chasing his very own Game of Thrones — a runaway hit that will allow Amazon's video streaming business to break into the big leagues of Hollywood. In MGM, the film studio behind storied franchises such as James Bond and Rocky, Bezos might have found what he is looking for. But many remain sceptical.

Why commuters won't easily be lured back to the office For the longest time, commuters have schlepped into the office because they had no choice. The pandemic, at least in New York City, may change that. Commuters have the power to demand change. They should use it, writes Josh Chaffin.

  • What can people do to ensure hybrid work is a success? The FT posed this question to its global panel of chief executives and business leaders in the latest instalment of Leaders' Lessons.

A return to the status quo is not guaranteed As Covid-19 lockdowns are scaled back, economic optimism is rising and investors and advisers are contemplating a boom decade. But the pandemic has exposed inequality and reminded people of how uncertain the future is, breeding a broad desire for reform, writes Gillian Tett.

Alexander Lukashenko calls the west's bluff Since deciding to divert an EU commercial plane with a military jet and arrest the opposition activist Roman Protasevich who was onboard, the president of Belarus has attracted western outrage and threats of economic sanctions. But Lukashenko, who has ruled the country for 27 years, is feeling stronger at home.

Angela Merkel has dealt Europe's authoritarian leaders a trump card Few can match the German chancellor in her rhetorical devotion to the rules-based international system. Vladimir Putin's ambitions are antithetical. He wants a return to the spheres of influence of power politics. Russia's president can do as he pleases in the knowledge the EU's reaction will be constrained by Berlin, writes Philip Stephens.

What's wrong with the Michelin guide? Even to its detractors, Michelin is the most influential restaurant guide on the planet. But there are three main accusations levelled against it: that it restricts creativity, that it cannot possibly cover that many restaurants, and that it is too “French”. Yet why is it that chefs still crave a star?

Podcast of the day

Washington's desire to find a Middle East solution Martin Indyk, a former US ambassador to Israel and US special envoy during the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, discusses with Gideon Rachman the Biden administration's stance on the Middle East crisis.
